awd_titl_txt: Controlling Cross-shore Sediment Transport by Integrating Pile Breakwaters with Wave Energy Converters for Sustainable Coastal Management
awd_abstract_narration:
1706938 (Huang). This research aims at solving two important problems, shoreline erosion and utilization of wave energy. The research explores the potential of an innovative breakwater design for shore protection and electricity generated by wave action. The long-term goal of this research is to promote the concept of coastal management with sustainable technologies.

Relying on recent developments in two-phase flow simulations, this research will improve understanding of hydrodynamic and sediment processes in the vicinity of bottom-sitting coastal structures of complex geometry. It will enable better prediction of shoreline evolution protected by an Oscillating Water Column (OWC)-pile breakwater. The project brings together two distinct research areas: wave energy utilization and shore protection. The marine energy industry is seeking ways to lower the deployment costs of wave power farms and the coastal engineering industry is seeking innovative ideas that can potentially revolutionize traditional coastal management practices. The outcomes of the proposed research have the potential to build a bridge between these two industries so that they can work together to make both of them profitable from sustainable shore-protection projects. The ability to generate electricity from shore-protection structures also makes a contribution to efforts to reduce carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. The DesignSafe CI is an end-to-end data management, analysis and publication platform supported by NSF. All experimental and numerical data as well as the algorithms and numerical codes developed in this work will be deposited in the DesignSafe Data Depot and made available for researchers. To promote public awareness of research findings and the concept of sustainable coastal management, the PI will make use of online platforms such as YouTube and ThinkTech Hawaii to reach a larger public audience.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Ocean waves contain tremendous energy, which is a nightmare to coastal engineers but good news for the renewable energy community.  Various shore-protection structures have been used to reflect and dissipate part of the energy in the waves approaching the shore; this part of wave energy, if not utilized as a renewable energy source, is wasted without generating economic value. However, the anticipated high construction cost has been a big hurdle to overcome in the commercialization of wave energy utilization.  

This project examined the integration of the oscillating-water-column (OWC) type of wave energy converters with a pile breakwater to make wave-energy utilization economically viable through cost-sharing between two structures.  The result of this integration is a dual-function structure for electricity generation and shore protection. Both numerical simulations and wave-flume tests were employed in this project to understand the performance of this dual-function coastal structure as a wave farm for electricity generation as well as a breakwater for shore protection. 

Waves flumes tests were performed to investigate (i) wave-induced scour at an OWC-pile (a single OWC unit in a dual-function structure), (ii) wave-induced scour at a pile breakwater and a dual-function structure, and (iii) the wave transmission through and wave-energy extraction by a dual-function structure. These wave-flume tests improved the understanding of the performance of the dual-function structure and potential issues associated with the foundation safety.  In particular, the wave-flume tests demonstrated that under typical coastal wave conditions, a full-scale dual-function structure of 1 km long could have a potential power output of about 1MW as well as a noticeable reduction of the wave power in the transmitted waves. The reduced wave transmission can mitigate the shoreline erosion.  However, the local scour at the dual-function structure needs to be addressed in the design of the structure's foundation.

Numerical simulations were performed to understand the flow characteristics near and the wave loading on an OWC-pile.  The numerical simulations generated the following findings: (i) Existence of strong vortices near the two ends of the C-shaped support of an OWC-pile is responsible for the deepened scour holes found in the wave-flume experiment. (ii) Sloshing inside an OWC chamber can be triggered by the vortex shedding from the lower skirt of the OWC chamber and thus can affect the determination of the OWC efficiency. (iii) Proper scales for the wave forces and overturning moments are identified. 

Several new methods and models were developed under the support of this award.  A multiphase flow model was developed that can simulate geophysical flow problems involving air, water and sediment (e.g., beach erosion and flow-induced local scour). A new VOF method was developed that can capture the air-water interface in the presence of suspended sediment.  A new method was developed to model the quadratic power-takeoff for oscillating water columns in CFD simulations; the new method can speed up the CFD simulations by at least a factor of 25.  A new model for particle response time, which is a parameter quantifying the drag between the fluid phase and the sediment phase, was developed to simulate the sediment in loose as well as dense packing conditions.  

Two graduate students were trained on performing wave flume tests, developing numerical models, performing numerical simulations on high-performance computing clusters, writing scientific papers, and presenting their research results at international conferences.  One undergraduate student participated in creating outreach materials based on the research results and findings of this project. 

One of the impacts of this project on other disciplines is an improved understanding of the impulse waves generated by granular landslides.  The multiphase flow model developed for this project has been applied successfully to numerical simulations of submarine/subaerial granular landslides to understand how factors such as an erodible bed and grain size can affect the landslide process and resulting impulse waves. 

 


Last Modified: 11/17/2021
Modified by: Zhenhua Huang
